docs.text: Welcome to MkDocs For full documentation visit mkdocs.org . Commands mkdocs new [dir-name] - Create a new project. mkdocs serve - Start the live-reloading docs server. mkdocs build - Build the documentation site. mkdocs -h - Print help message and exit. Project layout mkdocs.yml # The configuration file. docs/ index.md # The documentation homepage. ... # Other markdown pages, images and other files.

docs.text: WSL Install Goto the windows store to find various versions of linux distrobutions. Install and create username. Check Versions To see what the default distro is wsl -l Output: PS C:\Users\ashle> wsl -l Windows Subsystem for Linux Distributions: Ubuntu-18.04 (Default) To check which version of WSL each distro is using and if it is running. Open powershell. wsl -l -v Output: PS C:\Users\ashle> wsl -l -v NAME STATE VERSION * Ubuntu-18.04 Running 1 Set WSL2 as default In powershell run the following. wsl --set-default-version 2 Operations Open file from explorer Put the following in the browser to access files from within WSL. \\wsl$\[Distrobution] \\wsl$\Ubuntu-20.04 Troubleshooting Kernel Upgrade If you recieve this error PS C:\Users\ashle> wsl --set-version Ubuntu-20.04 2 Conversion in progress, this may take a few minutes... WSL 2 requires an update to its kernel component. For information please visit https://aka.ms/wsl2kernel You need to download a small kernal upgrade from the link above. Switch on Virtual Machine Platform If you get: PS C:\Users\ashle> wsl --set-version Ubuntu-18.04 2 Conversion in progress, this may take a few minutes... For information on key differences with WSL 2 please visit https://aka.ms/wsl2 Please enable the Virtual Machine Platform Windows feature and ensure virtualization is enabled in the BIOS. For information please visit https://aka.ms/wsl2-install Go into windows and features and tick Virtual Machine Platform. It wasn't ticked after upgrading to WSL2. Useful Links Windows WSL Guide YouTube Upgrade Video
docs.title: WSL

Open powershell. wsl -l -v Output: PS C:\Users\ashle> wsl -l -v NAME STATE VERSION * Ubuntu-18.04 Running 1

For information please visit https://aka.ms/wsl2-install Go into windows and features and tick Virtual Machine Platform. It wasn't ticked after upgrading to WSL2.

docs.text:
CSS selector{property : value;} Who{What : How;} Best Practice is to have all the properties in alphabetical order. TAG/Class/ID Selectors Styling tags will change properties across all HTML tags Class allows you to specified a new class per HTML tag. Headings can only be used in one place. TAG h2 { color: #00adb5; font-family: 'Segoe UI', Tahoma, Geneva, Verdana, sans-serif; } Class Class attribute differentiates between properties. .class1 { background-color: green; } .class2 { background-color: red; } ID #heading3 { background-color: blue; } Sudo Class Represented via : You append it to your class for extra functionality. img:hover { border-color: aquamarine; } .class4434:shadow { border-color: aquamarine; } CSS BOX Model p { margin: 1%; /* Gives space between any adjacent element */ border: 0px; /* */ padding: 2%; /* Increases the element to give padding to what's inside */ } Display Properties You have inline syntaxes such as and block syntaxes such as

Allows you to modify stuff without dropping it onto another line but you can't change the width in the class. You can modify a block syntax to be half way p { display: inline-block } Position Properties Static (HTML Rules) Relative (Position the element as if it would be static. Ex, 30px from the left) Coordinates (Top, Bottom, Left, Right). Relative positioning doesn't affect any other element. Absolute (Position the element relative to it's parent). It does effect the flow of the other elements. Fixed - Keeps the position of the element where it is on the page even if you scroll. Check out codepen.io for my saved examples. Dynamic Sizing When you change the browser settings to increase font this wont allow px text to change. (Using the Zoom feature will scale everything) Pixel - Static. Percent - If you use % you'll need to work out the conversion. 100% = 16px, 565.2 = 90px etc.. EM - Long story short 1em = 16px Dynamic values are inherited. Which means if you set body font size is 20% and H1 font size is 100% the H1 font will be 120%. REM - is root font size which means it wont inherit from anywhere else. This method is preferred. To convert https://www.w3schools.com/cssref/css_pxtoemconversion.asp Media Query @media Code Refactoring Readability Modularity Efficiency Length CSS Layouts: - Put all the HTML elements at the top. - The group everything else by sections - @media should be at the bottom. Pairing classes and elements together make for a more specific grouping. You read it right to left. .class h1 {color: red;} This says any h1 inside the specified class will be red. Any other h1 (child) outside the parent .class wont be affected.
docs.title: CSS

docs.text: Functions Indentations are either 2 spaces, 4 spaces or tab. Use any just be consistent. user = 'Gary' def welcome(user): print('Hello', user) print('Hope you are well') welcome(user) print('Hey') Global Variable Function name = 'Marselle' def welcome2(): print('Hello super user', name) welcome2() Divider Function def divider(symbol): print(symbol * 79) divider('-') Number Function num_var = input('What number do you want to divide? ') def div_two(num_var): return int(num_var)/2 print('And our lucky number is: ', div_two(num_var)) Using Lists with Functions (Positional Parameters) These need to represent the list order as this is positional parameters def sshNodes(p1, p2, p3, p4): print('Connection Name: ', p1) print('IP Address:', p2) print('Username:', p3) print('Password:', p4) user1List = ['R2901A', '192.168.50.1', 'ajoyner', 'london'] user2List = ['S3750B', '192.168.50.64', 'automation', 'london'] sshNodes(*user2List) Using Dictionaries with Functions (Keyword Parameters) These don't need to be in order as this is keyword not positional parameter def sshNodes2(node, ipaddr, username, password): print('Connection Name: ', node) print('IP Address:', ipaddr) print('Username:', username) print('Password:', password) user5list = { 'node' : 'A5501A', 'ipaddr' : '192.168.125.16', 'username' : 'movermars', 'password' : 'london', } sshNodes2(**user5list) User Number Ask user the number number100 = input("What's ya number? ") Function to convert the users number def multiply100(number100): return int(number100)*100 Print variable print(multiply100(number100)) To return multiple values you seperate with a comma def get_boundaries(target, margin): low_limit = target - margin high_limit = margin + target return(low_limit, high_limit) low, high = get_boundaries(100, 20) print(low) print(high)
docs.title: Functions

docs.text: Javascript Multiline Comment /* This is a multiline comment. Thank you Goodnight */ Type of Shows you what datatype is in the brackets. typeof(23); typeof("Ash"); typeof(true) Prompt (Input) To ask the user for a value var dogAge = prompt("What is your dogs age?"); String Concatination Make sure you put spaces between varaibles and + f var message = "Hello"; var name = "Marselle"; alert(message + name); Variables If you want to change the varable you only need to use the 'var' once after the container is created. var myName = "Marselle"; Prompts user for input var yourName = prompt("What is your name?"); Pops out an alert with the variable of myName alert("My name is " + myName + ". Welcome to my site " + yourName); String Length/Number Retrival Below is code I made to ask a message, display how many characters are in the message and work out the remaining characters if 280 is max. // Prompt that feeds into variable. var message = prompt("Whats your beef?"); // Variable that works out remainder var remainder = 280 - message.length // Display message alert("You have written " + message.length + " characters, you have " + remainder + " left."); It can also be written simpler by doing the maths within the alert using () . var message = prompt("Whats your beef?"); alert("You have written " + message.length + " characters, you have " + (280 - message.length) + " left."); String Slicing Using the slice() method you can specify what part of a string you want to include. Starts at 0 . var name = "Marselle" name.slice(2,3) > "r" // Range (Start at 3 up to but not including 7) name.slice(3,7) > "sell" Below will slice the output to be maximum of 140 characters var message = prompt("Whats your beef?"); var message = message.slice(0,140) alert(message); Single line version of above which will: 1. Prompt 2. Slice 3. Alert alert(prompt("Whats your beef?").slice(0,140)); Change String Case var name = "Marselle" name = name.toUpperCase(); > "MARSELLE" var name = "Marselle" name = name.toLowerCase(); > "marselle" String Case and Slice By using slice we can isolate which part of the variable we make upper case and whats lower case. Also as we don't know the length of the users name by starting the slice at 1 and then using the .length method we say make the second character and then the length of the variable lower case. var name = prompt("What is your name?"); alert(name.slice(0,1).toUpperCase() + name.slice(1,name.length).toLowerCase()); Maths Look at Python Maths for all mathmatical syntaxs. There's an order of presendence. * , % before + , - . 5 * 2 would come before 3 + 5 var cost = 3 + 5 * 2 If you wanted 3 + 5 to come first you would encase it in brackets. var cost = (3+5) * 2 It's good practice to add the parenthesis even though you know the multiplication or divison is happening first. var cost = 3 + (5 * 2) Increment/Decrement To increase a value use += & *= . To decrease a value use -= & /= . var x = 7; var y = 10; x += 2; > 9 y -= 6; > 4 Functions Functions is basically zipping up code that you reuse. // Create Function function funcName() { alert("Hello"); alert("World"); } // Call Function funcName();
docs.title: Javascript

docs.text: Lists & Dictionaries Lists They use square brackets. userAge = [18, 19, 22, 25, 30] You can print a particular value in a list. print(userAge[1]) 19 print(userAge[0]) 18 print(userAge[-1]) 30 You can have empty lists and fill them later with the apend() function emptyList = [] Make a list into a variable (variable = list) userAgeV1 = userAge Assign index to a variable. Notation 2:4 is known as a slice. userAgeV2 = userAge[2:4] print (userAgeV2) [22, 25] The third number in the slice is a stepper. We get a sublist consisting every second number. userAgeV3 = userAge[1:5:2] print (userAgeV3) [19, 25] Appending to a list router =['891','2901', '2951', '4001'] Append to existing list router.append('2950') #Append a list to a list router.append(['mx240', 'srx200']) Slice notations have useful defaults. The default for the first number is zero, and the default for the second number is size of the list being sliced. For instance, userAge[ :4] gives you values from index 0 to index 4-1 while userAge[1: ] gives you values from index 1 to index 5-1 (since the size of userAge is 5, i.e. userAge has 5 items). Tuple Tuples are just like lists, but you cannot modify their values. The initial values are the values that will stay for the rest of the program. To declare a tuple, you write tupleName = (initial values) . Use parentheses ( ) when declaring a tuple. Multiple values are separated by a comma. monthsOfYear = ("Jan", "Feb", "Mar", "Apr", "May", "Jun", "Jul", "Aug", "Sep", "Oct", "Nov", "Dec") print(monthsOfYear[4]) Dictionaries Dictionary is a collection of related data PAIRS. userAge = {'Bjorn':32, 'Hatti':18, 'Matthew':44} Or via a method userAge = dict(Bjorn = 32, Hatti = 18, Matthew = 44) To print a users age print(userAge['Bjorn']) Create empty dictinoaries to be filled in later userName = dict() Add to empty dictionary userName['John Smith'] = 'jsmith' Delete from dictionary del userName['John Smith'] Display list in easy to read format userCricket = { 'Brian Lara' : 'blara', 'Courtney Walsh' : 'cwalsh', 'Curtley Ambrose' : 'cambrose', 'Malcom Marshall' : 'mmarshall', }
docs.title: Lists & Dictionaries

docs.text: Tuples are just like lists, but you cannot modify their values. The initial values are the values that will stay for the rest of the program. To declare a tuple, you write tupleName = (initial values) . Use parentheses ( ) when declaring a tuple.
docs.title: Tuple

docs.text: monthsOfYear = ("Jan", "Feb", "Mar", "Apr", "May", "Jun", "Jul", "Aug", "Sep", "Oct", "Nov", "Dec") print(monthsOfYear[4])
docs.title: Multiple values are separated by a comma.

docs.text: Dictionary is a collection of related data PAIRS. userAge = {'Bjorn':32, 'Hatti':18, 'Matthew':44} Or via a method userAge = dict(Bjorn = 32, Hatti = 18, Matthew = 44)
docs.title: Dictionaries

docs.text: print(userAge['Bjorn'])
docs.title: To print a users age

docs.text: userName = dict()
docs.title: Create empty dictinoaries to be filled in later

docs.text: userName['John Smith'] = 'jsmith'
docs.title: Add to empty dictionary

docs.text: del userName['John Smith']
docs.title: Delete from dictionary

docs.text: userCricket = { 'Brian Lara' : 'blara', 'Courtney Walsh' : 'cwalsh', 'Curtley Ambrose' : 'cambrose', 'Malcom Marshall' : 'mmarshall', }
docs.title: Display list in easy to read format

docs.text: Python Basics Strings String Input Using the input function with strings. name = input('What is your name? ') age = input('What is your age? ') location = input('Where are you from? ') >>>print('Hello', name , 'how are you doing today? You are', age , 'today and based in the', location) Formatting Strings using the format() method The term {1:d} means variable 1 (40) and that its an integer. {0:s} first and a string. print('Hey {0:s}. You are {1:d} today. How is it in {2:s}?'.format('Ash',40,'Gower')) print('Hey {0:s}. You are {1:s} today. How is it in {2:s}?'.format(name,age,location)) Variables a = 1 _a = 'woop' To find the location in memory of a variable id(a) Shows what variables are in the interactive interpreter dir() Math Math Operators + addition - subtraction * multiplication / division // floor division % modulus ** exponent Variable x = 5 y = 2 Addition x + y Subtraction x - y Multiplication x*y Division x/y Floor Division (rounds down the anser to the nearest whole) x//y Modulus Gives the remainder when 5 is divided by 2) (Modulo isn’t division, but returns the remainder after performing division. x%y Exponent (5 to the power of 2) x**y Logic Not equal: 5 != 2 Greater than: 5>2 Smaller than: 2<5 Greater than or equal to: 5>=2 5>=5 2 <= 5 2 <= 2 IF Statement userInput = input('How old are you? ') if userInput >= 18: print('You may proceed adult') elif userInput < '18': print('Sorry you are under the legal age') else: print('We need to know your age before proceeding') For Loop For loop executes a block of code repeatedly until the condition in the for statement is no longer valid. String, list, tuple or dictionary can be looped.
docs.title: Python Basics

docs.text: Using the input function with strings. name = input('What is your name? ') age = input('What is your age? ') location = input('Where are you from? ') >>>print('Hello', name , 'how are you doing today? You are', age , 'today and based in the', location)
docs.title: String Input

docs.text: The term {1:d} means variable 1 (40) and that its an integer. {0:s} first and a string. print('Hey {0:s}. You are {1:d} today. How is it in {2:s}?'.format('Ash',40,'Gower')) print('Hey {0:s}. You are {1:s} today. How is it in {2:s}?'.format(name,age,location))
docs.title: Formatting Strings using the format() method

docs.text: Ubuntu Quick Fixes Error: Temporary failure resolving 'archive.ubuntu.com' This means the repos can't resolve DNS. Temp add nameserver echo "nameserver 8.8.8.8" | sudo tee /etc/resolv.conf > /dev/null Then do another update sudo apt update If this sorts the problem, permanently add the nameserver echo "nameserver 8.8.8.8" | sudo tee /etc/resolvconf/resolv.conf.d/base > /dev/null
docs.title: Ubuntu FAQ

docs.text: This means the repos can't resolve DNS.
docs.title: Error: Temporary failure resolving 'archive.ubuntu.com'

docs.text: echo "nameserver 8.8.8.8" | sudo tee /etc/resolv.conf > /dev/null
docs.title: Temp add nameserver

docs.text: sudo apt update
docs.title: Then do another update

docs.text: echo "nameserver 8.8.8.8" | sudo tee /etc/resolvconf/resolv.conf.d/base > /dev/null
docs.title: If this sorts the problem, permanently add the nameserver
